identificationModule.briefTitle: RIC (Remote Ischemic Conditioning) in Older Individuals
identificationModule.officialTitle: Feasibility and Acceptability of Remote Ischemic Conditioning to Achieve High-Intensity Rehabilitation Effects and Increase Resilience in Older Individuals

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to examine the feasibility and acceptability of a technique called remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) that aims to improve muscle strength, muscle mass, exercise tolerance, resilience (i.e. how well someone responds to a stressor), quality of life, physical activity, and physical function when added to rehabilitative exercise training in individuals over age 65 who have some difficulty with mobility.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Participants will be split into two different groups: one receiving the RIC intervention with low-intensity exercise and the other receiving a sham RIC intervention with low-intensity exercise. The assignment to the two different groups will be done by a computer in a process similar to flipping a coin in a 1:1 ratio. There will be 10 participants in each group.

armGroups.label: RIC Intervention
armGroups.description: RIC will be applied to the upper arm and then inflated and deflated in cycles. The cycles are 5 minutes long. There are 4 sets of cycles of intervention with inflation of the cuff (5 minutes ON) and deflation of the cuff (5 minutes OFF) for 35 minutes total. The amount of inflation will be pre-determined. This intervention will be completed 5 times per week.
interventionNames: Other: Remote Ischemic Conditioning (RIC) with low-intensity exercise

armGroups.label: Sham RIC Intervention
armGroups.description: RIC will be applied to the upper arm and then inflated and deflated in cycles. The cycles are 5 minutes long. There are 4 sets of cycles of intervention with inflation of the cuff (5 minutes ON) and deflation of the cuff (5 minutes OFF) for 35 minutes total. The amount of inflation will be pre-determined. This intervention will be completed 5 times per week.
interventionNames: Other: Remote Ischemic Conditioning (RIC) with low-intensity exercise

interventions.name: Remote Ischemic Conditioning (RIC) with low-intensity exercise
interventions.description: The intervention protocol will consist of low-intensity resistance exercise training plus RIC 3x/week for 6 weeks. Each visit will consist of 60 minutes of exercise and 35 minutes of RIC. RIC will also be completed 2 more times each week at home for the 6 week program duration.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Feasibility of study intervention as measured by the number of participants who completed the study
Feasibility of study intervention as measured by the attrition rate
primaryOutcomes.description: Attrition rate is expressed as a percentage and is calculated by dividing the number of non-completers by the total number of participants.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Feasibility of study intervention as measured by the number of exercise visits attended per participant
Feasibility of study intervention as measured by the number of RIC home applications completed per participant
Acceptability of study intervention as measured by an Intervention Acceptability Questionnaire
primaryOutcomes.description: Each participant will complete an Intervention Acceptability Questionnaire with responses on a 5-point Likert scale, where a higher score indicates greater acceptability.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Feasibility of collecting blood samples during study as measured by the success rate of collection
Change in Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB)
secondaryOutcomes.description: The SPPB measures changes in physical function.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in muscle strength as measured by dynamometry
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measurements made with isokinetic dynamometry, hand-held dynamometry and DXA scans completed at pre- and post-intervention.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in exercise tolerance as measured by VO2peak testing
Change in quality of life as measured by PROMIS-29
Change in Brief Resilience 5-point Likert Scale
Change in vascular function as measured by arterial tonometry
